text: [Music]
so there's three things to look out for
when you're spotting a fake number one
is to finish just check the weight of
the watch the quality of the finishings
if you're in doubt at all then you're
probably holding a fake there is also a
number of markings on the watch to look
out for in the finish as the markings on
the dial check the brands been spelt
correctly check that the buckle emblems
are all correct the second thing to look
for is is sort of an industry standard
thing which is to look and check if it's
ticking or sweeping if it's ticking
that means it's got a battery-powered
movement which in in any Rolex wouldn't
wouldn't happen because every Rolex has
an automatic movement so the hand will
always sweep and the third thing
probably to just keep an eye out for is
checking the serial numbers that needs
to be done by somebody who can remove
the bracelet there should be serial
numbers at either end of the case and
they're on the modern Rolexes there's a
serial number at the bottom of the dial
so if they're not there then you've
definitely probably got a fake any watch
that's priced at 50 pounds online and
you're hoping is a real Rolex is highly
unlikely to be the real watch in the
equivalent of this one would cost nearly
20 or just over 20,000 pounds at retail
and that's something which I'd
immediately point out and make you aware
that you shouldn't be purchasing a watch
and expecting it to be real in that case
you
you
